[ before noun ] (of a skirt or dress) very short and covering only the very top part of the leg: She was wearing a silver mini dress. Compare
maxi
midi
[ before noun ] much smaller or less serious than the usual type: I made a batch of mini muffins. There's a mini fridge in each hotel room. It was just a mini worry. Nothing serious.
informal small in size: British women are mini compared to some other European women - in fact they may be the shortest in Europe.

Grammar
Diminutives (-let, -y and mini-)A diminutive creates a meaning of ‘small’ or ‘little’. The most common diminutives are formed with the prefix mini- and with suffixes such as -let and -y. We often use a diminutive with names or with abbreviated names when we want to be more informal, or to express affection for someone or something: …
a brand name for a type of small British car first made in the 1960s
